message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Learning agile soccer skills for a bipedal robot with deep reinforcement learning
Paper Abstract: We investigated whether deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is able to synthesize sophisticated and safe movement skills for a low-cost, miniature humanoid robot that can be composed into complex behavioral strategies. We used deep RL to train a humanoid robot to play a simplified one-versus-one soccer game. The resulting agent exhibits robust and dynamic movement skills, such as rapid fall recovery, walking, turning, and kicking, and it transitions between them in a smooth and efficient manner. It also learned to anticipate ball movements and block opponent shots. The agent’s tactical behavior adapts to specific game contexts in a way that would be impractical to manually design. Our agent was trained in simulation and transferred to real robots zero-shot. A combination of sufficiently high-frequency control, targeted dynamics randomization, and perturbations during training enabled good-quality transfer. In experiments, the agent walked 181% faster, turned 302% faster, took 63% less time to get up, and kicked a ball 34% faster than a scripted baseline.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed a web search for "Soccer" and retrieved comprehensive information. Here's an overview of what I found:

## What is Soccer?

Association football, more commonly known as football or soccer, is a team sport played between two teams of 11 players who almost exclusively use their feet to propel a ball around a rectangular field called a pitch.(no content)Internationally, association football is governed by FIFA.

## Terminology

The term soccer comes from Oxford "-er" slang, which was prevalent at the University of Oxford in England from about 1875, initially spelt assoccer (a shortening of "association"), it was later reduced to the modern spelling.

## Professional Soccer in the United States

Major League Soccer (MLS) is a professional soccer league in North America and the highest level of the United States soccer league system. It comprises 30 teams, with 27 in the United States and 3 in Canada, and is sanctioned by the United States Soccer Federation.(no content)The Philadelphia Union are the current Supporters' Shield holders, having won their second title in 2025, while the current MLS Cup champion is Inter Miami CF, winning their first title in 2025.

## Popularity and Participation

Soccer is the fourth most popular sport in the United States behind American football, basketball, and baseball, respectively.(no content)As of 2023, over 240 million people play soccer in the United States.

Soccer is the fourth most popular sport in the United States behind American football, basketball, and baseball, respectively.(no content)As of 2023, over 240 million people play soccer in the United States.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of deep reinforcement learning:

## Definition and Overview

Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning (RL) and deep learning.(no content)RL considers the problem of a computational agent learning to make decisions by trial and error.(no content)Deep RL incorporates deep learning into the solution, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.

## Key Capabilities

Deep RL algorithms are able to take in very large inputs (e.g. every pixel rendered to the screen in a video game) and decide what actions to perform to optimize an objective (e.g. maximizing the game score).

## Applications

Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

## Notable Achievements

In the past decade, deep RL has achieved remarkable results on a range of problems, from single and multiplayer games such as Go, Atari Games, and Dota 2 to robotics. Some specific milestones include:

- Beginning around 2013, DeepMind showed impressive learning results using deep RL to play Atari video games, outperforming competing methods on almost all the games and performing at a level comparable or superior to a professional human game tester.
- Deep reinforcement learning reached another milestone in 2015 when AlphaGo, a computer program trained with deep RL to play Go, became the first computer Go program to beat a human professional Go player without handicap on a full-sized 19×19 board.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about reinforcement learning:

## Overview

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## Key Characteristics

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment. 

A fundamental aspect of RL is the exploration-exploitation tradeoff: To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

## Applications

It has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.

## Subfields and Variants

Some important areas within reinforcement learning include:

- **Deep Reinforcement Learning**: Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning (RL) and deep learning, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.

- **Multi-agent Reinforcement Learning**: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

- **Model-free Algorithms**: In reinforcement learning (RL), a model-free algorithm is an algorithm which does not estimate the transition probability distribution (and the reward function) associated with the Markov decision process (MDP), which, in RL, represents the problem to be solved.

Links: [{"title":"Transfer of learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_of_learning"},{"title":"Transfer learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_learning"},{"title":"Simulations and games in industry education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulations_and_games_in_industry_education"},{"title":"Synthetic data - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthetic_data"},{"title":"Virtual reality in nursing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_reality_in_nursing"},{"title":"Simulation hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation_hypothesis"},{"title":"Simulated reality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulated_reality"},{"title":"Instructional simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instructional_simulation"},{"title":"Knowledge distillation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_distillation"},{"title":"Federated learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federated_learning"}]

I found search results related to your query on "Transfer learning simulation to reality." Here are the key findings:

## Transfer Learning in Machine Learning

Transfer learning is a technique in machine learning in which knowledge learned from a task is re-used in order to boost performance on a related task.(no content)For example, for image classification, knowledge gained while learning to recognize cars could be applied when trying to recognize trucks.

## Simulation to Reality Transfer

A significant application of transfer learning involves training models on synthetic data and then applying them to real-world scenarios. Synthetic data is increasingly being used for machine learning applications: a model is trained on a synthetically generated dataset with the intention of transfer learning to real data. 

However, there are challenges: Transfer learning remains a nontrivial problem, and synthetic data has not become ubiquitous yet. Research results indicate that adding a small amount of real data significantly improves transfer learning with synthetic data.

## Practical Applications

Federated learning is used to learn vision-based navigation, helping better sim-to-real transfer. This is particularly relevant for robotics applications where models trained in simulation environments need to work in real-world conditions.

The search results indicate that while transfer learning from simulation to reality is an active area of research with promising applications, it remains challenging and typically benefits from incorporating some real-world data alongside synthetic training data.

Links: [{"title":"Transfer of learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_of_learning"},{"title":"Transfer learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_learning"},{"title":"Simulations and games in industry education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulations_and_games_in_industry_education"},{"title":"Synthetic data - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthetic_data"},{"title":"Virtual reality in nursing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_reality_in_nursing"},{"title":"Simulation hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation_hypothesis"},{"title":"Simulated reality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulated_reality"},{"title":"Instructional simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instructional_simulation"},{"title":"Knowledge distillation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_distillation"},{"title":"Federated learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federated_learning"}]

I found search results related to your query on "Transfer learning simulation to reality." Here are the key findings:

## Transfer Learning in Machine Learning

Transfer learning is a technique in machine learning in which knowledge learned from a task is re-used in order to boost performance on a related task.(no content)For example, for image classification, knowledge gained while learning to recognize cars could be applied when trying to recognize trucks.

## Simulation to Reality Transfer

A significant application of transfer learning involves training models on synthetic data and then applying them to real-world scenarios. Synthetic data is increasingly being used for machine learning applications: a model is trained on a synthetically generated dataset with the intention of transfer learning to real data. 

However, there are challenges: Transfer learning remains a nontrivial problem, and synthetic data has not become ubiquitous yet. Research results indicate that adding a small amount of real data significantly improves transfer learning with synthetic data.

## Practical Applications

Federated learning is used to learn vision-based navigation, helping better sim-to-real transfer. This is particularly relevant for robotics applications where models trained in simulation environments need to work in real-world conditions.

The search results indicate that while transfer learning from simulation to reality is an active area of research with promising applications, it remains challenging and typically benefits from incorporating some real-world data alongside synthetic training data.

Web search results for query: "Humanoid robot"

Links: [{"title":"Humanoid robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanoid_robot"},{"title":"Category:Humanoid robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Humanoid_robots"},{"title":"Sophia (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophia_(robot)"},{"title":"Humanoid Robotics Project - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanoid_Robotics_Project"},{"title":"International Journal of Humanoid Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Journal_of_Humanoid_Robotics"},{"title":"1X Technologies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1X_Technologies"},{"title":"Atlas (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlas_(robot)"},{"title":"Leju Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leju_Robot"},{"title":"Valkyrie (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valkyrie_(robot)"},{"title":"Ai-Da - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ai-Da"}]

I've successfully performed a web search for "Humanoid robot." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition and Purpose

A humanoid robot is a robot resembling the human body in shape.(no content)The design may be aimed at functional purposes, such as interacting with human tools and environments and working alongside humans, for experimental purposes, such as the study of bipedal locomotion, or for other purposes.

## Historical Background

The concept of humanoid robots dates back centuries. In the 3rd century BCE, a Taoist philosophical text called the Liezi detailed the idea of a humanoid automaton, including mention of an engineer named Yan Shi who created a life-size, human-like robot for the fifth king of the Chinese Zhou Dynasty, King Mu.(no content)In the 13th century, a Muslim engineer named Ismail al-Jazari designed various humanoid automata, including a waitress robot that would dispense drinks from a liquid reservoir.

## Modern Applications

Humanoid robots are a valuable resource in medicine and biotechnology, as well as other fields of research, and are being used to develop complex prosthetics for individuals with physical disabilities such as missing limbs.(no content)Humanoid robots can be used as test subjects for the practice and development of personalized healthcare aids, essentially performing as robotic nurses for demographics such as the elderly.

## Notable Contemporary Examples

The search results include information about several modern humanoid robots including Atlas (developed by Boston Dynamics), Sophia, Valkyrie (developed by NASA), and NEO (from 1X Technologies), among others.

Web search results for query: "Robotics control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Control,_Robotics,_and_Autonomous_Systems"},{"title":"Robot control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_control"},{"title":"Motion control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_control"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IISc_Guidance,_Control_and_Decision_Systems_Laboratory"},{"title":"Robotics engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics_engineering"},{"title":"Automation technician - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automation_technician"},{"title":"Sea Machines Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_Machines_Robotics"},{"title":"FANUC - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FANUC"},{"title":"PLC technician - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PLC_technician"},{"title":"Galip Ulsoy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galip_Ulsoy"}]

I've completed a web search for "Robotics control systems." Here's an overview of what I found:

## Key Information About Robotics Control Systems

**Control Methods**
Robotics can be controlled by various means including manual, wireless, semi-autonomous (a mix of fully automatic and wireless control), and fully autonomous (using artificial intelligence).

**Control System Architecture**
The basic architecture of a motion control system contains: A motion controller, which calculates and controls the mechanical trajectories (motion profile) an actuator must follow (i.e., motion planning) and, in closed loop systems, employs feedback to make control corrections and thus implement closed-loop control.

**Closed-Loop Systems in Robotics**
Most robots rely on closed-loop control systems, where sensors provide continuous feedback to adjust movements and behaviors.

**Role of Engineers**
Robotics engineers design control algorithms that manage the interaction between sensors, actuators, and software. Additionally, Artificial intelligence (AI) is used in robotic control to make it able to process and adapt to its surroundings. It is able to be programmed to do a certain task, for instance, walk up a hill.

**Applications**
Motion control systems are extensively used in a variety of fields for automation purposes, including precision engineering, micromanufacturing, biotechnology, and nanotechnology.

The search results provide comprehensive information on the fundamental principles, architectures, and applications of robotic control systems.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the web search results, I found several types of randomization, but the most relevant to "dynamics randomization" appears to be a random dynamical system, which is a dynamical system in which the equations of motion have an element of randomness to them.

The search results also revealed other related concepts:

1. **Degree-Preserving Randomization**: This is used to understand networks against otherwise random variation while maintaining the degree distributional aspect of the network.

2. **Random Dynamical Systems in Mathematics**: Formally, a random dynamical system consists of a base flow, the "noise", and a cocycle dynamical system on the "physical" phase space.

3. **General Randomization**: Randomization is a statistical process in which a random mechanism is employed to select a sample from a population or assign subjects to different groups.

If you're looking for information about a specific application of dynamics randomization (such as in robotics, machine learning, physics, or another field), please let me know and I can search for more targeted information.

Web search results for query: "Neural networks"

Links: [{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network"},{"title":"Neural network (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(biology)"},{"title":"History of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"Convolutional neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"Energy-based generative neural network","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy-based_generative_neural_network"},{"title":"Physical neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_neural_network"},{"title":"Mathematics of neural networks in machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics_of_neural_networks_in_machine_learning"},{"title":"Feedback neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_neural_network"}]

I've completed a web search for "Neural networks." Here's a comprehensive overview of the results:

## What Are Neural Networks?

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)In machine learning, a neural network is an artificial mathematical model used to approximate nonlinear functions.

## Basic Structure

Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).(no content)A network is typically called a deep neural network if it has at least two hidden layers.

## Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

## Training Process

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.(no content)Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network.

## Types of Neural Networks

The search results cover several specialized types, including convolutional neural networks (for image processing), graph neural networks (for structured data), and feedback neural networks (used in reasoning language models).

Links: [{"title":"Bipedalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bipedalism"},{"title":"Facultative bipedalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facultative_bipedalism"},{"title":"Zero moment point - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_moment_point"},{"title":"Robert D. Gregg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_D._Gregg"},{"title":"Jeffrey Meldrum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Meldrum"},{"title":"Humanoid robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanoid_robots"},{"title":"Bipedal gait cycle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gait_Cycle"},{"title":"Glossotherium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossotherium"}]

Here are the search results for bipedal locomotion:

## Definition and Basic Concepts

Bipedalism is a form of terrestrial locomotion where an animal moves by means of its two rear (or lower) limbs or legs.(no content)An animal or machine that usually moves in a bipedal manner is known as a biped, meaning 'two feet' (from Latin bis 'double' and pes 'foot').

## Types of Movement

Types of bipedal movement include walking or running (a bipedal gait) and hopping. More specifically, within the category of bipedal locomotion, there are four main techniques: walking, running, skipping, and galloping.

## Advantages of Bipedalism

Bipedalism raises the head; this allows a greater field of vision with improved detection of distant dangers or resources, access to deeper water for wading animals and allows the animals to reach higher food sources with their mouths.(no content)While upright, non-locomotory limbs become free for other uses, including manipulation (in primates and rodents), flight (in birds), digging (in the giant pangolin), combat (in bears, great apes and the large monitor lizard) or camouflage.

## Bipeds in Nature

Several groups of modern species are habitual bipeds whose normal method of locomotion is two-legged. In the Triassic period some groups of archosaurs, a group that includes crocodiles and dinosaurs, developed bipedalism; among the dinosaurs, all the early forms and many later groups were habitual or exclusive bipeds; the birds are members of a clade of exclusively bipedal dinosaurs, the theropods.(no content)Within mammals, habitual bipedalism has evolved multiple times, with the macropods, kangaroo rats and mice, springhare, hopping mice, pangolins and hominin apes such as australopithecines, including humans, as well as many other extinct groups.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Kuffner Jr. - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_J._Kuffner_Jr."},{"title":"Configuration space (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Configuration_space_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Bruce Donald - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruce_Donald"},{"title":"Raja Chatila - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raja_Chatila"},{"title":"Dan Halperin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Halperin"}]

## Motion Planning in Robotics

Here's an overview of motion planning in robotics based on the search results:

### Definition and Purpose

Motion planning, also known as path planning or the navigation problem, is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration and a goal configuration, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.

### Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video games, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.

### Key Algorithms and Approaches

Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions (robotic manipulators, biological molecules, animated digital characters, and legged robots).

Other major approaches include:
- Grid-based approaches that overlay a grid on configuration space and assume each configuration is identified with a grid point
- Real-time path planning methods that can adapt to real-time changes in the environment

### Real-World Applications

For example, in navigating a mobile robot inside a building to a distant waypoint while avoiding walls and not falling down stairs, a motion planning algorithm would take a description of these tasks as input and produce the speed and turning commands sent to the robot's wheels.

Based on the search results, here's information about bipedal gait robots:

## What is Bipedal Gait?

Bipedalism is a form of terrestrial locomotion where an animal or machine moves by means of its two rear (or lower) limbs or legs, with an animal or machine that moves in this manner known as a biped.

## Key Characteristics

The periodic contact of the legs of the robot with the ground is called the gait of the walker.(no content)In humanoid robots, the planning must carry out biped motions, meaning that robots should plan motions similar to a human.

## Notable Bipedal Robots

Several important bipedal robots have been developed:

- MABEL is well known for being the world's fastest bipedal robot with knees, able to reach speeds of up to 3.6 m/s (6.8 mph).

- ATRIAS is a bipedal robot developed by researchers at Oregon State University's Dynamic Robotics Laboratory that is capable of walking on two legs at about 3 miles per hour.

- Cassie set the Guinness World Record for 100M run by a bipedal robot.

- Honda has developed a number of humanoid robots that use a bipedal gait, starting with the experimental E series in the mid-1980s and culminating with the autonomous ASIMO.

## Advantages and Challenges

Legged motion makes it possible to negotiate uneven surfaces, steps, and other areas that would be difficult for a wheeled robot to reach. However, the question of walking biped robots stabilization on the surface is of great importance, with maintenance of the robot's gravity center over the center of bearing area being necessary for providing a stable position.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Learning agile soccer skills for a bipedal robot with deep reinforcement learning". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes new methodology)

**Triples Extracted:** 9 key technologies and methodologies

The analysis identified the following technologies and methodologies used and proposed by the paper:

### Methods Used:
1. **Deep reinforcement learning** - The primary ML technique for training the robot
2. **Reinforcement learning** - Foundational paradigm for the deep RL approach
3. **Transfer learning** - Enables sim-to-real zero-shot transfer
4. **Robot control** - High-frequency control mechanisms for movement synthesis
5. **Neural network (machine learning)** - Deep learning architecture for the RL agent

### Artifacts/Systems:
1. **Humanoid robot** - The physical bipedal system being trained

### Task Domain:
1. **Association football (Soccer)** - The competitive domain

### Concepts:
1. **Bipedalism** - The walking locomotion form the robot masters

### Proposed Contribution:
1. **Robot locomotion** - Novel approach to learning sophisticated robot movement skills through deep RL

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation script confirms the JSON structure is correct with all required fields present.

Sources:
- [Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning)
- [Humanoid robot - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanoid_robot)
- [Association football - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_football)
- [Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning)
- [Transfer learning - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_learning)
- [Robot control - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_control)
- [Bipedalism - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bipedalism)
- [Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning))
- [Robot locomotion - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_locomotion)
